messages.text:
Oops sorry for the nuisance! a couple of things to check:
1. if you’re using `fd2html` in a `hfun` , make sure to pass `internal=true` otherwise page variables are reset and you don’t want that; normally you’re not supposed to use `fd2html` in a hfun (if you’re producing markdown, you should use a lxfun but that’s another discussion)
2. if your hfun needs to ensure that all pages have been processed before being executed properly (so that it has access to all page vars properly), then you need to add `@delayed`  in front of the function definition (see <http://franklinjl.org/demos|franklinjl.org/demos>)
If (1) or (2) don’t help, maybe tag me in your repo explaining in more details what you were trying to do and I’ll have a look?
Note: here’s a relevant example in the wild: <https://github.com/JuliaLang/www.julialang.org/blob/d825a89cf0c470930faee6c618436cb74ed1c8f3/utils.jl#L63-L66>

messages.text: A small puzzle. I edited a line in an already published blog post, and uploaded it fine. But JuliaBloggers decided to re-tweet every entry in the RSS/XML feed.xml, which was bad, because retweeting old nonsense posts from 5 years ago is bad. :slightly_smiling_face: I suppose `__site/feed.xml` is getting rewritten (because everything in there is?) each time Franklin updates, but the actual contents (inc dates) shouldn't have changed, I think. So somewhere along the line JuliaBloggers is checking the incoming RSS/XML feed and deciding that it's all worth repeating again. Not a current problem but if anyone has any thoughts about why this happens, and how to stop it....

elements.text: A small puzzle. I edited a line in an already published blog post, and uploaded it fine. But JuliaBloggers decided to re-tweet every entry in the RSS/XML feed.xml, which was bad, because retweeting old nonsense posts from 5 years ago is bad.
I suppose
__site/feed.xml

is getting rewritten (because everything in there is?) each time Franklin updates, but the actual contents (inc dates) shouldn't have changed, I think. So somewhere along the line JuliaBloggers is checking the incoming RSS/XML feed and deciding that it's all worth repeating again. Not a current problem but if anyone has any thoughts about why this happens, and how to stop it....

messages.text:
I have a bunch of blog posts that are in the following folder format

```content
├── 00.md
├── 01.md
├── 02.md```
But they are rendered on my current blog as:

```<http://website.com/unique-name-for-00.html|website.com/unique-name-for-00.html>
<http://website.com/unique-name-for-01.html|website.com/unique-name-for-01.html>
<http://website.com/unique-name-for-02.html|website.com/unique-name-for-02.html>```
I have two questions:

1) I believe I can create a `@url = unique-name-for-00` inside each file and that'll handle the name of the url. Is my understanding correct?
2) Currently, I believe the url will still be `<http://website.com/content/unique-name-for-dd.html|website.com/content/unique-name-for-dd.html>`. Is there a way to remove the `content` from the final `__site` folder structure, but preserve it in the source markdown folder?

elements.text: I have a bunch of blog posts that are in the following folder format

content
├── 00.md
├── 01.md
├── 02.md
But they are rendered on my current blog as:

website.com/unique-name-for-00.html
website.com/unique-name-for-01.html
website.com/unique-name-for-02.html

I have two questions:

1) I believe I can create a
@url = unique-name-for-00

inside each file and that'll handle the name of the url. Is my understanding correct?
2) Currently, I believe the url will still be
website.com/content/unique-name-for-dd.html
. Is there a way to remove the
content
from the final
__site
folder structure, but preserve it in the source markdown folder?

messages.text:
Small note for those interested that there is now (in 0.10.21) a new page variable `slug` that allows you to specify the final URL for a page. This should be considered a "beta" feature for now and feedback is welcome.
If you have a page `00-foo.md` and you add `@def slug = "bar/baz"` the final HTML page will be written at `__site/bar/baz/index.html` and therefore be available at `{base_url}/{prepath}/bar/baz/` . Thanks to <@ULGMQ3LCB> for the suggestion and happy :christmas_tree: to all.

elements.text: Small note for those interested that there is now (in 0.10.21) a new page variable
slug

that allows you to specify the final URL for a page. This should be considered a "beta" feature for now and feedback is welcome.
If you have a page
00-foo.md
and you add
@def slug = "bar/baz"
the final HTML page will be written at
__site/bar/baz/index.html
and therefore be available at
{base_url}/{prepath}/bar/baz/
. Thanks to
for the suggestion and happy
to all.

messages.text:
<@UDP5WL2RX> after going through a few of my existing files and converting it from Pandoc Markdown to Franklin Markdown by hand, I'm realizing that it might be easier if I use a `hfun_pandocify` type function to read the current file's markdown convert it to html, and insert it into the current page. However, when I do this, naturally, the original markdown content also exists below the content I've hfun inserted.

Any recommendations for dealing with this?

Hi,
I created a basic version of my webpage using Franklin in Julia. The github repo is here:
<https://github.com/sumitrmishra/sumitrmishra.github.io>
Now, I made some changes locally to the webpage, but I am unable to deploy these changes. I used `publish()` from within REPL, but that doesn't show up on gh-pages.
What am I missing? Apologies for such a trivial question.

Warm regards,
Sumit

messages.text: Hey all! I feel bad pinging <@UDP5WL2RX> and other maintainers about issues I am running into that are easily solvable. I tried searching for Franklin developer docs - is there anything like this that I am missing? Does anyone have any suggestions to help with learning about the Franklin codebase? Many thanks! :juliaheartpulse-dark:

messages.text:

<https://notes.andymatuschak.org/>

messages.text: Thanks so much to the `Franklin.jl` developers! I'm making a personal site with `Franklin.jl`, but for some reason the site renders locally, but not with GitHub pages. I double checked that I'm publishing the `gh-branches` branch. I posted the issue on <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/deploying-username-github-io-with-franklin-jl/52966|Discource> as well. Has anyone ran into this issue before?

attachments.title: Deploying username.github.io with Franklin.jl
attachments.text: I’m trying to publish a static webpage to <http://cadojo.github.io|cadojo.github.io> with Franklin.jl (my username is cadojo on GitHub). When I use Franklin.serve(), the webpage loads as expected: However, when I check the version published at <http://cadojo.github.io|cadojo.github.io>, the page doesn’t seem to actually be rendered. There are still @def commands visible at the top of the page: I’ve double checked that I am indeed publishing to the gh-pages branch, and I don’t believe I’ve modified the deploy.yml file at all. I’m trying t...

hfun_

{{randomquote}}

messages.text: On a related question, considering I am publishing the site to github pages, how can I add a README.md and a LICENSE that would be pulled to the github pages repo? As I understand it, README.md, at least, will be processed to a `/README/index.html`, so it won’t work, right?

messages.text: Finally, notice I am writing a bilingual site, so I have a boolean variable to say whether it is currently to be view as Portuguese or not, and if not, it turns to English. But what if I want more languages? (I don’t, this is just an example to my following question) It would be simpler to have a `language` variable that could assume one of many possible values, say `"pt"`, `"en"`, `"es"`, and so on. Then I would like to check the case with `{{ if language == "pt"}} … {elseif language == "en"}} … {{elseif …}} … {{end}}` . But I understand ifs  only work with boolean variable and tests above do not work, is that so? At least I tried and it didn’t work.

. But I understand ifs  only work with boolean variable and tests above do not work, is that so? At least I tried and it didn’t work.

messages.text:
A couple of questions regarding using lunr+github pages: the documentation says
```If you are experimenting locally, just call lunr() then serve() and test that searching works as expected.
When you are ready to update your website you can [...] call publish(final=lunr),```
however the deploy documentation says
`
```If you use GitHub or GitLab with a deployment action on those platforms, you do not need to use publish, you can just push your changes and let the relevant action do the rest on the platform```
so my question is: should I modify the `deploy.yml`  file to generate the search index (I guess adding `lunr()` somewhere), or does the (latest) default deploy file already takes care of it?

elements.text: A couple of questions regarding using lunr+github pages: the documentation says

If you are experimenting locally, just call lunr() then serve() and test that searching works as expected.
When you are ready to update your website you can [...] call publish(final=lunr),

however the deploy documentation says
`
If you use GitHub or GitLab with a deployment action on those platforms, you do not need to use publish, you can just push your changes and let the relevant action do the rest on the platform
so my question is: should I modify the
deploy.yml
file to generate the search index (I guess adding
lunr()
somewhere), or does the (latest) default deploy file already takes care of it?

messages.text:
a few more deployment related questions
1. I checked the gh-actions log and I have a bunch of `
```GKS: Open failed in routine OPEN_WS
GKS: GKS not in proper state. GKS must be either in the state WSOP or WSAC in routine ACTIVATE_WS
/home/runner/.julia/packages/GR/BwGt2/src/../deps/gr/bin/gksqt: error while loading shared libraries: libQt5Widgets.so.5: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
connect: Connection refused
GKS: can't connect to GKS socket application```
should I be worried about these?
2. I also seem to have a few issues with `highlight.js`. The log says `
```Couldn't find highlight.js (``/home/runner/.julia/artifacts/a42f5c72a500a8683c08a5e818d27a104fc9cd5a/bin/node` -e "require('highlight.js')"` failed).
→ It is required for pre-rendering highlight.js but is not necessary to run Franklin (cf docs).
→ After installing any missing component, please re-build the package (cf docs).
[...]
+ highlight.js@10.5.0
added 1 package from 295 contributors and audited 1 package in 0.361s
found 0 vulnerabilities

┌ Warning: I couldn't load 'highlight.js' so will not be able to pre-render code blocks. You can install it with `npm install highlight.js`.
└ @ Franklin ~/.julia/packages/Franklin/eCeWy/src/manager/post_processing.jl:42```
The highlight otherwise works fine, but I I seem to lose rows numbering of the code (which works locally). I have run `npm install highlight.js`. Any ideas what might be causing it?

messages.text: Is there an emacs org-mode workflow for publishing with Franklin?

elements.text: Is there an emacs org-mode workflow for publishing with Franklin?

messages.text: org-mode is an alternative markup from markdown. there are convenient programs for publishing “wiki”s of connected files from org-mode by exporting from emacs to html, markdown, or other pipelines that can hook into static site generators like Jekyll or Hugo.

root.text: Is there an emacs org-mode workflow for publishing with Franklin?

elements.text: Is there an emacs org-mode workflow for publishing with Franklin?

org-mode is an alternative markup from markdown. there are convenient programs for publishing “wiki”s of connected files from org-mode by exporting from emacs to html, markdown, or other pipelines that can hook into static site generators like Jekyll or Hugo.

messages.text: <@UPJ6Q2SQY> I'm not exactly sure what your issue is; but given you're not the only one asking about "inserting markdown in markdown", I've written a simple demo that can be copy pasted: <https://franklinjl.org/demos/#013_inserting_markdown_in_markdown>; it works with maths, code etc. Maybe try it, and if it doesn't do what you want, please open an issue on GitHub directly with a reproducing example that doesn't do what you'd like? we can discuss there whether we could directly add another feature for everyone.

messages.text:
I have a question about choosing a good workflow. The blog part of my site works well with Franklin, but I had some photo galleries before which I want to add to the Franklin site as well.

I have folders with "originals" at relatively good resolution and thought it should be reasonably straightforward to make a script that goes through these folders, computes smaller preview / thumbnail versions, and then creates the pages that show them.

What I'm confused about is where to put the main script, where to generate the pages with images, where to best store the thumbnails (they should only be generated at deployment).

Currently I have a main `index.md` in a `photography` top folder, and in that only the command `{{ generate_galleries }}`. The images are in the `_assets` folder in one subfolder per album. Do I generate `md` files in `hfun_generate_galleries` and put them in subfolders of `photography`? I don't have a good understanding where in the build sequence I should insert my generated content. Should I generate the thumbnails into the generated `asset` folder?
